comment:
One of the most solid systems in the very
solid by nature Nimzo Indian Defence. It has been played many times in World
Chess Championship matches - it's a sign of quality by itself.

Vassily tries to find something less well known. According to my
database this move was played for the first time in 1983 by Hungarian GM A.
Adorjan. Black wants to exchange his b and c-pawns for White's c and d-pawns
and gain a pawn majority in the center. Of couse Black loses out on 
development after that.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 b6 4. g3 Ba6 5. b3 b5 6. cxb5 Bxb5 7. Bg2 c5 8. O-O Bc6 9. Ba3 Na6 10. Nbd2 Be7 11. dxc5
comment:
Vladimir plays in a classical manner - he simply develops his
pieces and will try to use his extra-tempos.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 b6 4. g3 Ba6 5. b3 b5 6. cxb5 Bxb5 7. Bg2 c5 8. O-O Bc6 9. Ba3 Na6 10. Nbd2 Be7 11. dxc5 Bxc5 12. Bxc5 Nxc5 13. Rc1 Nb7 14. e4
1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 b6 4. g3 Ba6 5. b3 b5 6. cxb5 Bxb5 7. Bg2 c5 8. O-O Bc6 9. Ba3 Na6 10. Nbd2 Be7 11. dxc5 Bxc5 12. Bxc5 Nxc5 13. Rc1 Nb7 14. e4 O-O
comment: Ivanchuk decided to reject this "gift". In case of

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 b6 4. g3 Ba6 5. b3 b5 6. cxb5 Bxb5 7. Bg2 c5 8. O-O Bc6 9. Ba3 Na6 10. Nbd2 Be7 11. dxc5 Bxc5 12. Bxc5 Nxc5 13. Rc1 Nb7 14. e4 O-O 15. Nd4
comment:
As Zigbert
rasch said: "One piece placed bad - all game is bad!". The b7 Knight isn't
only bad by itself, it also stops the c6 Bishop retreating. As a result Black
will have a weak pawn on the c-file.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 b6 4. g3 Ba6 5. b3 b5 6. cxb5 Bxb5 7. Bg2 c5 8. O-O Bc6 9. Ba3 Na6 10. Nbd2 Be7 11. dxc5 Bxc5 12. Bxc5 Nxc5 13. Rc1 Nb7 14. e4 O-O 15. Nd4 Rc8 16. Nxc6 dxc6 17. Qe2 Qc7 18. Rc2 Rfd8 19. Rfc1 h6 20. h3
comment:
Vladimir doesn't hurry.
Black hasn't any real counterplay. If Black plays e6-e5 (to restrict the g2
Bishop), than White will play h3-h4 and Bh3, and Black will have problems with
protecting the c6-pawn.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 b6 4. g3 Ba6 5. b3 b5 6. cxb5 Bxb5 7. Bg2 c5 8. O-O Bc6 9. Ba3 Na6 10. Nbd2 Be7 11. dxc5 Bxc5 12. Bxc5 Nxc5 13. Rc1 Nb7 14. e4 O-O 15. Nd4 Rc8 16. Nxc6 dxc6 17. Qe2 Qc7 18. Rc2 Rfd8 19. Rfc1 h6 20. h3 Nd7 21. Nf3 Qb6 22. e5
comment: At the best moment! Now the d7 knight  can't go to d5 via f6 or b6.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 b6 4. g3 Ba6 5. b3 b5 6. cxb5 Bxb5 7. Bg2 c5 8. O-O Bc6 9. Ba3 Na6 10. Nbd2 Be7 11. dxc5 Bxc5 12. Bxc5 Nxc5 13. Rc1 Nb7 14. e4 O-O 15. Nd4 Rc8 16. Nxc6 dxc6 17. Qe2 Qc7 18. Rc2 Rfd8 19. Rfc1 h6 20. h3 Nd7 21. Nf3 Qb6 22. e5 c5 23. Nd2 Na5 24. Nc4
comment:
White is free of prejuduce.  The "Bad" knight can take
the d4-square so it has to be exchanged.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 b6 4. g3 Ba6 5. b3 b5 6. cxb5 Bxb5 7. Bg2 c5 8. O-O Bc6 9. Ba3 Na6 10. Nbd2 Be7 11. dxc5 Bxc5 12. Bxc5 Nxc5 13. Rc1 Nb7 14. e4 O-O 15. Nd4 Rc8 16. Nxc6 dxc6 17. Qe2 Qc7 18. Rc2 Rfd8 19. Rfc1 h6 20. h3 Nd7 21. Nf3 Qb6 22. e5 c5 23. Nd2 Na5 24. Nc4 Nxc4 25. Rxc4 Qc7 26. b4 Qxe5 27. Qxe5 Nxe5 28. Rxc5 Rxc5 29. bxc5
comment:
When Kramnik has a passed pawn he is twice as dangerous as usual! Another
very important point (apart from the passed pawn.) - in this open position the
Bishop is stronger than the Knight.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 b6 4. g3 Ba6 5. b3 b5 6. cxb5 Bxb5 7. Bg2 c5 8. O-O Bc6 9. Ba3 Na6 10. Nbd2 Be7 11. dxc5 Bxc5 12. Bxc5 Nxc5 13. Rc1 Nb7 14. e4 O-O 15. Nd4 Rc8 16. Nxc6 dxc6 17. comment: Very precise play. Now the Black King has to go away from the passed pawn.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 b6 4. g3 Ba6 5. b3 b5 6. cxb5 Bxb5 7. Bg2 c5 8. O-O Bc6 9. Ba3 Na6 10. Nbd2 Be7 11. dxc5 Bxc5 12. Bxc5 Nxc5 13. Rc1 Nb7 14. e4 O-O 15. Nd4 Rc8 16. Nxc6 dxc6 17. comment: First of all White has to activate his King. Too early was
